pages.title: Sales Tip – Basics — Tip 1
pages.content: Sales Tip – Basics — Tip 1 ← Back ⤒ Intro Suggest edit Dev notes Admin Sales Tip – Basics Silent Internal Triggers (No Customer Involvement) Context Core Principle (Teach This First) You don’t escalate because you’re slow — you escalate because accuracy matters. The customer never needs to know why assistance is needed — only that it improves the outcome. A trainee should automatically seek assistance if any one of the following is true: The part is not dimensionally standard The application involves load, speed, or safety The customer says “this keeps failing” The part has attachments, modifications, or damage The trainee is choosing between two similar options The part will be hard to return once installed These are non-negotiable escalation points. pages.title: Sales Tip – How We Add Value — Tip 1
pages.content: Sales Tip – How We Add Value — Tip 1 ← Back ⤒ Intro Suggest edit Dev notes Admin Version: 1.28.2 • Last updated: 2026-02-07 Sales Tip – How We Add Value Phrases That Undermine Confidence Context (Even when the info is correct) ❌ “I’m not really sure…” ❌ “I think this is right…” ❌ “I don’t know much about these…” ❌ “I’ve never seen one of these before…” Why to avoid: They instantly hand control to the customer and invite pressure or dismissal. Say instead: ✔ “Let’s check this properly.” ✔ “We’ll confirm the details.” ✔ “I want to make sure this matches.” Next → Suggest edit This creates an email draft to the manual admin. pages.content: Sales Tip – How We Add Value — Tip 2 ← Back ⤒ Intro Suggest edit Dev notes Admin Version: 1.28.2 • Last updated: 2026-02-07 Sales Tip – How We Add Value Phrases That Invite Guessing (And future returns) ❌ “It should be fine.” ❌ “That’ll probably work.” ❌ “People usually use this.” ❌ “This is close enough.” Why to avoid: They sound casual — and casual parts fail. Say instead: ✔ “This matches the dimensions.” ✔ “This suits that application.” ✔ “This is the correct type for that setup.” ← Previous Next → Suggest edit This creates an email draft to the manual admin. pages.content: Sales Tip – How We Add Value — Tip 3 ← Back ⤒ Intro Suggest edit Dev notes Admin Version: 1.28.2 • Last updated: 2026-02-07 Sales Tip – How We Add Value Phrases That Challenge the Customer (Creates resistance and ego conflict) ❌ “That’s wrong.” ❌ “You can’t use that.” ❌ “Who told you that?” ❌ “That’s not how it works.” Why to avoid: Even if true, they trigger defensiveness. pages.title: Sales Tip – How We Add Value — Tip 4
pages.content: Sales Tip – How We Add Value — Tip 4 ← Back ⤒ Intro Suggest edit Dev notes Admin Version: 1.28.2 • Last updated: 2026-02-07 Sales Tip – How We Add Value Phrases That Over-Promise Expertise (Risky and unnecessary) ❌ “I know exactly what you need.” ❌ “Trust me.” ❌ “I’ve been doing this for years.” ❌ “This is definitely the best option.” Why to avoid: If anything goes wrong, these come back hard. Say instead: ✔ “Based on what you’ve described…” ✔ “This is the correct match for that setup.” ✔ “This aligns with the application.” ← Previous Next → Suggest edit This creates an email draft to the manual admin. pages.content: Sales Tip – How We Add Value — Tip 7 ← Back ⤒ Intro Suggest edit Dev notes Admin Version: 1.28.2 • Last updated: 2026-02-07 Sales Tip – How We Add Value Phrases That Give Away Control (Especially with confident customers) ❌ “What do you want to do?” ❌ “Up to you.” ❌ “You tell me.” ❌ “Whatever you think.” Why to avoid: You’re the guide — not the passenger. Say instead: ✔ “Here’s what I recommend.” ✔ “This is the correct path for that issue.” ✔ “This option avoids the common problems.” ← Previous Next → Suggest edit This creates an email draft to the manual admin. pages.content: Sales Tip – How We Add Value — Tip 8 ← Back ⤒ Intro Suggest edit Dev notes Admin Version: 1.28.2 • Last updated: 2026-02-07 Sales Tip – How We Add Value Phrases That Devalue Measurement (Dangerous in bearings, seals, belts, chain) ❌ “That looks about right.” ❌ “They’re usually all the same.” ❌ “It should fit.” Why to avoid: Dimensions are everything in mechanical parts. Say instead: ✔ “Let’s confirm the measurements.” ✔ “Once we measure it, it’s clear.” ✔ “Size will tell us.” ← Previous Next → Suggest edit This creates an email draft to the manual admin.
